p.content: Nominal phrases can be very complex. This section concentrates on those with common nouns as the lexical head. Modification by articles, demonstratives, possessors, quantifiers and degree words, adjective phrases, and
phrases is considered. Participles and gerunds are covered at the end of this section, but see section
for noun compounds whether or not they are written as a single word. Nominal phrases headed by proper names are discussed in section
and those headed by pronouns, demonstratives, and quantifiers are handled in section
. Relative clauses, which normally come at the end of a nominal phrase, are covered in section
The basic order of elements allowed in nominal phrases in
is:
Each of these phrases will be discussed and exemplified in the following sections.
Working from the outside in toward the noun, the outer level of the nominal phrase is occupied by those degree words that modify the whole phrase, such as
, and
. These were discussed in section
To review the facts for

, the positive forms are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase. The positive special degree elements are

case.caseText: phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

The following chart summarizes how all the special degree elements are expressed in

The following chart summarizes how all the special degree elements are expressed in

Articles and/or demonstratives normally comprise the next level moving inward towards the noun. In English, articles and demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, but they both occur before the noun. Some languages allow both to co-occur in the same phrase, and they may occur in different positions with respect to the noun. Therefore, they need distinct syntactic categories. Some languages only have one set, either articles or demonstratives. A few languages may not have either type expressed as separate words.
As seen in section

case.caseText: does not have either articles or demonstratives that are realized as separate words.
has only articles that are realized as separate words, no demonstratives.
has only demonstratives that are realized as separate words, no articles.
has both articles and demonstratives that are realized as separate words.

There are restrictions as to which of the articles may appear on either side of the noun.

In many languages, possessors comprise the next level moving inward towards the noun. Possession can normally be expressed by a pronoun, by a simple noun, or by a full nominal phrase. However, Spanish only allows pronouns in the possessor position before the noun, with all noun and full nominal phrase possessors expressed in a prepositional phrase with
after the noun.
Within the languages which express possessors by nouns or full nominal phrases as well as by pronouns, many also add some kind of marking, such as the

in English, as an indication of possession. These markings are either affixes (or clitics) on the head noun or phrase-level clitics which attach to one end of the whole phrase. The English marking is this second type, because alongside phrases where the
appears to attach to the head noun, as in
, there are phrases which clearly show that the clitic attaches to the end of the whole nominal phrase, such as
p.langData: the boy that I just talked to’s mother
p.content: or
p.langData: the girl in green’s wonderful speech
p.content: . These examples show that possessors can include
phrases and relative clauses. Possessors can also be embedded in one another, as in
. This is allowed in Spanish within the prepositional phrase after the noun.
Examples of possessed nominal phrases with simple and embedded possessors in
include:
Examples with
phrases within the possessor include:
Examples with relative clauses within the possessor, included in simple full sentences are:
As seen in the examples above,

case.caseText: does not have any special marking to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.
marks the head noun within the possessor with an affix to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.
marks the whole phrase with a phrasal clitic to distinguish possessors from any other nominal phrase.

text.content: This phrasal clitic is an enclitic which attaches to the final word in the possessor.
This phrasal clitic is an proclitic which attaches to the first word in the possessor.
This phrasal clitic is written as a separate word which occurs
the possessor. The possessive clitic is

p.content: The possessor (especially the pronoun form, if
is like Spanish) occurs
the noun being possessed.
In English, possessors and articles or demonstratives do not co-occur in the same nominal phrase, unless the possessor is expressed in a prepositional phrase. For example,
is ungrammatical; instead one would use
to express the same thought. Some languages allow both possessors and articles or demonstratives to occur in the same phrase, so the first example above would be grammatical.
In
nominal possessors
occur in the same phrase as
in the normal possessor position

text.content: the possessor is expressed in a
phrase.

p.content: Quantifier phrases fill the next level inward toward the noun. This position includes both numbers (section
) and other quantifiers and degree words (section
). Such modifiers mark the number of the whole nominal phrase. English examples of quantified nominal phrases include:
and
p.langData: only the first one hundred boys
p.content: . All the quantifier phrases occur before the noun in English.
In
, quantifier phrases occur

case.caseText: on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of

p.content: the noun.

text.content: All of quantifier phrases can occur on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of the quantifier phrases can occur on each side of the noun.
All of the numbers occur before the noun.
All of the numbers occur after the noun.

p.content: examples of quantified nominal phrases include:
Like other modifiers within the nominal phrase, quantifier phrases in
show agreement with the head noun in
Adjective phrases were discussed earlier in section
. Adjective phrases occur close to the noun, yielding nominal phrases such as:
p.langData: just those very few old, dirty books
all the boy’s many black dogs
p.content: and
p.langData: only the first one hundred very eager young boys
p.content: . As the English examples show, adjectives all occur before the noun, and, unlike the other modifiers discussed so far, more than one adjective phrase is allowed.
In
, adjective phrases occur

case.caseText: on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of

p.content: the noun.

case.caseText: Prepositional and Postpositional Phrase Modifiers or Complements
Prepositional and/or Postpositional Phrase Modifiers or Complements

p.content: Both simple and compound nouns may have
phrase modifiers or complements, such as in
and
. In addition, genitive
phrases may take the place of the possessor, such as
and
. In English, the prepositional phrase always comes after the noun.
In
, the
phrase occurs
the head noun.
examples with
phrase modifiers or complements include:
See section
for more details on
phrases in
Participles or participle phrases may also act as adjectives in modifying a noun. Some English examples with the participle or participle phrase bracketed include:
and
Examples in
include:

Another case which may look like a noun and a complement may actually be a gerund or gerund phrase. This whole phrase occupies a normal argument position, such as subject, object, indirect object or the object of a preposition. Some English examples in full sentences with the gerund phrase bracketed include:
p.langData: [Studying participles] is challenging, He likes [reading Latin poetry]
p.content: and
p.langData: The receiver showed his worth by [making the catch].
p.content: Such phrases may be possessed or be modified as well, and sometimes only the gerund stands alone as the head of a nominal phrase, as in
and
Therefore, we will allow gerund phrases to occupy the head of the nominal phrase.
Examples from
of gerunds or gerund phrases that can take the place of a noun in a nominal phrase include:
These gerund phrases can be used in full sentences as shown here:
